questions.question: What is the primary goal of predictive modeling?

options.B: To identify patterns in past data to forecast future outcomes.

questions.question: Which of the following is a supervised learning technique used for prediction?

options.B: Principal Component Analysis (PCA)

questions.question: What type of predictive modeling is used when the target variable is continuous?

options.B: Clustering

questions.question: Which algorithm is a popular linear model used for regression?

options.B: Support Vector Machine (SVM)

questions.question: What is the purpose of splitting a dataset into training and testing sets in predictive modeling?

options.A: To increase the size of the dataset.
options.B: To evaluate the performance of the model on unseen data.
options.C: To make the model training faster.

questions.question: Which of the following is a common metric used to evaluate the performance of a regression model?

options.B: Precision

questions.question: What type of predictive modeling is used when the target variable is categorical?

options.B: Clustering

questions.question: Which algorithm is a tree-based classification technique?

options.B: Logistic Regression

questions.question: What is the purpose of a confusion matrix in classification?

options.A: To visualize the distribution of data points.
options.B: To evaluate the performance of a classification model by showing the counts of true positives, true negatives, false positives, and false negatives.
options.C: To identify the most important features in the data.
options.D: To reduce the dimensionality of the data.

questions.question: Which of the following is a common metric used to evaluate the performance of a classification model?

options.B: Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE)

questions.question: What is the goal of Logistic Regression?

options.B: To group data points into clusters.
options.C: To predict the probability of a binary outcome.
options.D: To reduce the number of features in the data.

questions.question: What are ensemble methods in predictive modeling?

options.B: Methods that combine the predictions of multiple models to improve overall performance.
options.C: Algorithms that work well with small datasets.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of an ensemble method?

options.B: K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN)

questions.question: What is feature engineering in predictive modeling?

options.A: The process of selecting the best machine learning algorithm.
options.B: The process of transforming raw data into features that better represent the underlying problem to the predictive models.
options.C: The process of evaluating the performance of a model.
options.D: The process of deploying a model into production.

questions.question: What is the purpose of cross-validation in predictive modeling?

options.A: To increase the training data size.
options.B: To get a more robust estimate of the model's performance by training and evaluating it on multiple subsets of the data.
options.D: To visualize the model's decision boundaries.

questions.question: What is regularization in the context of linear models?

options.A: A technique for handling missing values.
options.B: A method to prevent overfitting by adding a penalty term to the model's loss function.
options.C: A way to select the most important features.

questions.question: Which of the following is a time series forecasting technique?

options.B: K-Means Clustering

questions.question: What is the bias-variance tradeoff in predictive modeling?

options.A: The tradeoff between model complexity and interpretability.
options.B: The tradeoff between the amount of training data and model performance.
options.C: The tradeoff between a model's tendency to underfit (high bias) and overfit (high variance) the data.
options.D: The tradeoff between different evaluation metrics.

questions.question: What is hyperparameter tuning in machine learning?

options.A: The process of training the model on the entire dataset.
options.B: The process of selecting the best values for the parameters within a model.
options.C: The process of selecting the best values for the settings that control the learning algorithm.
options.D: The process of evaluating the model's performance on the test set.

questions.question: Why is model interpretability important in some predictive modeling applications?

options.A: It always leads to better predictive accuracy.
options.B: It helps in understanding why a model makes certain predictions, which is crucial for trust, debugging, and regulatory compliance in some domains.
options.C: It makes the model training process faster.
options.D: It reduces the complexity of the model.
